Healthcare worker behavior and compliance are critical components in preventing healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). This theme includes studies that focus on monitoring hand hygiene practices, training healthcare workers, and using technology to improve compliance. Research in this area often involves the development and evaluation of automated systems for hand hygiene adherence, the impact of peer effects on compliance, and the use of mobile applications to record and provide feedback on hand hygiene practices. Understanding and improving healthcare worker behavior is essential for reducing the spread of infections within healthcare facilities.

Social network analysis is a powerful tool for understanding the interactions and relationships within healthcare settings. This theme explores how social networks influence healthcare practices, such as vaccination uptake and infection control. Studies in this area examine the structure of healthcare worker contact networks, the small-world properties of these networks, and the application of network theory to optimize healthcare outcomes. By analyzing social networks, researchers can identify key influencers, optimize vaccination strategies, and develop interventions to improve healthcare practices and reduce the spread of infections.

Infection control and disease spread are critical areas of research in healthcare epidemiology. This theme includes studies that focus on modeling and controlling the spread of infections within healthcare facilities. Research in this area often involves the use of sensor networks to study healthcare worker movements, the impact of architectural changes on pathogen dynamics, and the development of models to predict and mitigate the spread of infections. Understanding the dynamics of disease spread and implementing effective infection control measures are essential for preventing outbreaks and protecting patient health.

Effective surveillance and monitoring are essential for early detection and control of infectious diseases. This theme encompasses research on various methods and technologies for disease surveillance, including the identification of surveillance site locations, the use of novel data sources like Craigslist and Wikipedia for disease tracking, and the optimization of sentinel surveillance networks. Studies in this area aim to improve the accuracy and efficiency of disease monitoring, enabling timely interventions and reducing the impact of outbreaks.

Methodological approaches in healthcare research involve the development and application of innovative techniques to improve data analysis and outcomes. This theme includes studies on representation learning, computer vision, sensor networks, and statistical models for network data. Researchers in this area focus on creating new methods for analyzing complex healthcare data, developing algorithms for disease prediction, and improving the accuracy of healthcare models. By advancing methodological approaches, researchers can enhance the quality and impact of healthcare research.

Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) is a significant concern in healthcare settings due to its high morbidity and mortality rates. This theme includes research on the risk factors, transmission dynamics, and spatial clustering of CDI. Studies in this area aim to identify asymptomatic cases, understand the impact of healthcare exposures on CDI risk, and develop strategies to mitigate infection spread. By focusing on CDI, researchers can improve infection control practices and reduce the burden of this challenging healthcare-associated infection.

Vaccination strategies are crucial for preventing infectious diseases and protecting public health. This theme explores various approaches to optimize vaccination among healthcare workers and the general population. Research in this area includes targeted vaccine subsidies, vaccination games with peer effects, and the use of prediction markets to forecast influenza outbreaks. By developing effective vaccination strategies, researchers can enhance vaccine uptake, reduce the spread of infections, and improve overall health outcomes.

text:
FacultyStudentsResearch StaffAlumni









BIJAYA ADHIKARI








Assistant Professor, Department of Computer Science
Bijaya Adhikari’s research focuses on data mining and machine learning, particularly on dynamical processes such as disease spread and misinformation on large networks. He is involved in AI for influenza forecasting, outbreak detection in hospitals, and network embedding. Bijaya received the prestigious NSF CAREER Award to develop online algorithms to combat Healthcare Associated Infections (HAIs) and Antimicrobial Resistance Organisms (AMROs) outbreaks. He has also received multiple travel awards for his contributions to conferences like KDD, SDM, and ICDM.








TED HERMAN








Professor Emeritus, Department of Computer Science
Ted Herman specializes in distributed systems and sensor networks. His research includes distributed algorithms with self-stabilization properties and the development of energy-efficient, reliable sensor networks. Ted has been recognized for his pioneering work in peace studies and was instrumental in founding the Peace Studies Program at Colgate University.








AARON MILLER








Assistant Professor, Department of Epidemiology
Aaron Miller’s research interests include disease surveillance, epidemiological methods, and infectious disease modeling. He uses large administrative data sources and novel data like smartphone-connected thermometers for real-time influenza forecasting. Aaron received the KL2 Scholar Award from the University of Iowa’s Institute for Clinical and Translational Science (ICTS) to improve the diagnosis and treatment of Parkinson’s disease.








SRIRAM PEMMERAJU








Professor, Department of Computer Science
Sriram Pemmaraju’s research is in theoretical computer science, focusing on distributed graph algorithms. He also works on disease diffusion, inference, and mitigation on contact networks within healthcare settings. Sriram received an NSF grant for his research project on the communication cost of distributed computation.











PHILIP POLGREEN








Professor, Department of Internal Medicine
Philip Polgreen’s research involves computational epidemiology, focusing on disease surveillance and identifying novel risk factors using structured and unstructured data. His work spans infectious and chronic diseases. Philip has been recognized as a Castle Connolly Top Doctor for ten consecutive years.








ALBERTO SEGRE








Professor and Chair, Department of Computer Science
Alberto Segre’s research focuses on distributed algorithms for discrete optimization problems, with applications in biological and health sciences. He co-founded the CompEpi group and works on epidemiological simulation and modeling. Alberto has received numerous awards, including the Fulbright Scholar, Faculty Scholar, and Outstanding Mentor Award.








JACOB SIMMERING








Assistant Professor, Department of Internal Medicine
Jacob Simmering’s research examines the effects of environmental factors like pollution and weather on health outcomes, particularly pulmonary diseases. He uses large healthcare databases and remote sensing measurements. Jacob received the KL2 Scholar Award from the University of Iowa’s ICTS and has been honored with the Best Research Papers award by the Carver College of Medicine.








DANIEL K SEWELL








Associate Professor, Department of Biostatistics
Daniel Sewell’s research includes statistical models for network data, clustering, and infectious disease modeling. He is interested in Bayesian statistics, statistical computation, and data visualization. Daniel has been inducted into the Delta Omega Honorary Society in Public Health and has received several awards within the UI College of Public Health, including the New Faculty Research Award, Junior Faculty Research Opportunity Award, and Faculty Teaching Award.

From Li et al. (2024): An agent-based simulation study, using real-world healthcare worker location data from a small nursing home, compared several strategies for mitigating infectious disease outbreaks like COVID-19 under varying conditions. Regular screening and isolation reduced the attack rate by 27%, while inter-resident contact restrictions were more effective, lowering it by 35%. Combining both interventions was highly effective. Reducing healthcare worker presenteeism had a moderate impact, but altering work schedules did not. The study suggests that while universal contact restrictions are very effective, restricting inter-resident contact to small groups, especially with weekly testing, could be a valuable strategy in high-risk situations to protect vulnerable nursing home residents.

From Zhong et al. (2024): Detecting hidden asymptomatic spread in healthcare epidemics is challenging due to data limitations and the difficulty of linking individual risk with transmission. This paper introduces a new approach, framing asymptomatic case detection as a Prize Collecting Steiner Tree problem on a temporal network and solving it with deep Q-learning. Evaluations on simulated CDI and COVID-19 outbreaks in real healthcare networks show our method significantly outperforms existing approaches in identifying asymptomatic cases (up to 29.62%), leading to better prediction of symptomatic cases. A real CDI outbreak case study supports the high-risk nature of our detected asymptomatic cases.

From Miller et al. (2023): This large matched case-control study used insurance claims data to evaluate the risk of community-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) across individual antibiotic types. Analyzing antibiotic prescriptions within 30 days prior to CDI diagnosis in 159,404 cases and 797,020 controls, the study identified clindamycin and later-generation cephalosporins as having the highest CDI risk, while minocycline and doxycycline had the lowest. The findings demonstrate significant variation in CDI risk among different antibiotics, which can inform antibiotic prescribing and stewardship strategies. Risk estimates were also found to be sensitive to the antibiotic exposure window considered.

title: Acknowledgments
text:
Our research involves the use of computational tools to model, simulate, visualize and, in general, understand the spread of disease. Our goal is to inform public and hospital policy decisions with respect to disease surveillance, disease prevention measures, and outbreak containment.
